CurNotes: The art department has secured for exhibition in the art room, 13 H.H., during this week, with the exception of Monday and Friday Afternoons, a collection of about thirty paintings of Japan's greatest artist, Hokusai, who flourished in the first quarter of the present century. These paintings exhibit the succesive stages in the development of Hokisai's art, the earliest dating from about 1780 and the latest from 1849. The works are especially valuable to Americans, showing a scheme of art entirely unknown to Occidentals. The delicate silk on which the paintings are made, the vertical line predominating throughout his work, instead of the horizontal line, the crude but vigorous broad stroke effects, particularly in the earlier productions, together with the unusual landscapes and figures common to all Oriental art, all tend to make this exhibition of exceptional importance to both art critic and layman.

ExhTitle: Four Artists: Alice Adams, Alice Aycock, Jackie Ferrara, Mary Miss

CurNotes: In January 1977, Robert Morris constructed a large sculptural piece in the courtyard of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute. Assisted by ten students together with local machinists and glaziers, Morris built twelve freestanding aluminum frames for eight by seven foot sheets of plate glass mirror. The large mirrors were placed at right angles in each corner of the courtyard and two double-faced sets were places in the center of the room. The resulting piece was a multi-reflecting mirror maze that extended the courtyard infinitely in any direction.

Serial Thinking: Selections from the LeWitt Collection and the Permanent Collection
CurNotes: Selected primarily from a group of works on extended loan from artist Sol LeWitt, this Kroh-McClelland Gallery exhibition featured prints and unique objects by contemporary American and European artists. One non-contemporary exception was a group of photographs by the early 20th-century German photographer Karl Blossfeldt. Blossfeldt's visually straightforward and systematic documentation of botanical subjects set the tone for the other serial works in this exhibition. Sculptures by William Beckley, Sol LeWitt, and Robert Morris complimented the repetitive and conceptual nature of the exhibition's two-dimensional works.
